It is completely arbitrary where we define voltage to equal zero, which we opted to do at point A.   This just means that voltage at C is less than voltage at A.  Since voltage at C is still less than voltage at B, this means that current flows through R1 from B to C.  The current would be reversed, if there were more voltage at C than at D, but that isn't the case.  To think about this in the hydraulic world, suppose you build a pipeline network with Pump 1 that lifts the water 12 meters above your deck, and then it drops through valve 1 and downspout to point C, which is 0.5 meters below your deck.  You then use pump 2 to lift the water another 8 meters, where it is now 7.5 meters above your deck.  Now the water has to drop down through another valve and downspout to return to its starting point on your deck.   The water is still lifted by the pumps, and falls naturally through the valves and downspouts, so no current is flowing opposite the way it should, through each of the given elements.  The fact that your deck is 0.5 meters above the water's lowest point, is irrelevant to the fact that the water is still flowing with an elevation increase through the pumps, and an elevation drop through the valves and downspouts.

Ideally, it is converted into chemical energy, which itself is a form of electric potential energy.  What it is doing, is corroding one of the electrodes, and restoring the other electrode to its elemental or alloy state.  If the battery is not suitable for backfeed, it would convert this energy into thermal energy, which is a practice you generally should avoid doing, as it could damage the battery if it overheats this way.

Electrons move towards positive terminal and current moves in the opposite direction to electrons, which makes sense

Assume you live at a time before we discovered the electron.  Assume it is positive charges that flow.   That is what conventional current is.   It usually doesn't matter which charges are flowing, and it is an artifact of history that current is assigned against the actual flow of electrons.   Either sign of charge could be flowing, and the same current would create the same effect on the circuit.

Nice explanation; the only thing is your sign convention is backwards. Engineers in the US use the passive sign convention. The voltage across a circuit element is positive only if current flows into the positive terminal of said element. The implications of the passive convention are that energy absorbed by an element is positive while energy supplied by an element is negative. (You essentially add up the voltage drops and subtract the voltage rises.)

It is arbitrary where we define electric potential to equal zero.   You simply pick a point and call it zero, and measure everything else relative to it.  Just like you can measure vertical position from any reference height that is convenient for you: the tabletop, the floor, the ground, sea level, etc.  Zero Volts is simply wherever you place the black probe of the Voltmeter.   Place the red probe at the same point, and absent any contribution of Faraday's law of induction, you will measure the same voltage on the red probe, and thus a voltage difference of zero Volts.

Can anyone please explain me how the hack is current flowing from + to + terminal 😭😭

You can assume current flows any direction you want.  If it turns out you are wrong, you'll simply end up with a negative sign on your answers, that you then interpret as current in the opposite direction.  In general, you take an educated guess by picking a battery, and basing it on current flowing out of the positive terminal of the battery, and returning to the negative terminal.   If current flows out of a battery, it means it is delivering power, if current flows in to a battery, it means it is charging.

12 amps across a 2 ohm resistor yields a voltage drop of 24 volts.  This leaves 76 Volts and 12 amps entering the parallel branch of the circuit.  Voltage is constant in a parallel circuit and the current will follow each path, the lowest path 5 ohms, will have the highest amount of current, all 3 branches will add to 12 amps.  you can find the total R of the branches using the reciprocal, but since you do not have any unidentified value you should be able to manipulate ohms law to find the current in each branch, the last resistor is in series, ohm's law with the 12 amps. across a 3.33 ohm resistor.  76 V-39.96 V = 36.04.  that is the total voltage drop in the parallel portion of the circuit over the 3 resistors respectively.

Because we said so.  It is based on the sign convention we set for electric charges, before we knew which sign of charges were actually flowing.  Turns out, it is really electrons flowing out of the negative terminal and back to the positive terminal.  But we still treat it the same as if it were positive charges flowing out of the positive terminal.

@abdulrahman.2014k I’m in college now for aero. I would say do not rely on your professors to learn a topic. This channel will do most of your early classes and if you’re an engineer your early classes are your hard ones not your speciality classes. Understand trigonometry well that’s more important than any other math as calculus uses it so heavily. Before exams do multiple example problems so you can do the exam quickly as a lot of exams are not hard if you had unlimited time but they are hard because of the short amount of time you get to do them.
